Genesis 27 , Jacob's Deception and the Stealing of the Blessing
The Aged Patriarch: Isaac's Blindness and Intention
The chapter opens with a portrait of patriarchal decline that sets the stage for all that follows: וַיְהִי כִּי־זָקֵן יִצְחָק וַתִּכְהֶיןָ עֵינָיו מֵרְאֹת (wayehi ki-zaqen Yitschaq wattikhheyna 'eynav mere'ot), "And it came to pass when Isaac was old and his eyes were dim so that he could not see." The verb כָּהָה (kahah), "to grow dim, faint, weak," describes the progressive failure of Isaac's vision, a physical deterioration that carries profound symbolic weight throughout the narrative. Isaac's blindness is not merely a medical condition but a narrative device that exposes the deeper blindness of a father who would bless the son of the flesh over the son of promise, who would follow his appetite for game rather than the divine oracle given to his wife, who would attempt to reverse by patriarchal authority what God had decreed before the twins' birth.

The phrase מֵרְאֹת (mere'ot), "from seeing," indicates complete or near-complete loss of sight; Isaac cannot perceive visually what stands before him. This physical incapacity becomes the condition of possibility for the entire deception, Jacob could never have impersonated Esau before sighted eyes. Yet the blindness also symbolizes Isaac's spiritual condition: he cannot see what should be evident, cannot perceive the divine purpose that has been operating since the womb, cannot discern between the son who despised the birthright and the son who valued it. The patriarch who received theophanies and covenant renewals now gropes in darkness, both physical and spiritual, attempting to accomplish by blessing what God has determined shall not be accomplished.

Isaac summons his elder son with paternal affection: וַיִּקְרָא אֶת־עֵשָׂו בְּנוֹ הַגָּדֹל (wayyiqra' 'et-'Esav beno haggadol), "and he called Esau his elder son." The designation הַגָּדֹל (haggadol), "the elder" or "the great one," emphasizes the natural precedence that Isaac intends to honor. Despite the oracle declaring that the elder would serve the younger, despite Esau's sale of the birthright to Jacob, despite Esau's marriages to Hittite women that brought bitterness to both parents, Isaac persists in treating Esau as the rightful heir of blessing. The term בְּנוֹ (beno), "his son," with the singular possessive, subtly suggests Isaac's particular attachment to Esau; this is the son whom Isaac claims as specially his own, the son whose taste for game matches Isaac's appetite, the son of the field whom the tent-dwelling father inexplicably prefers.

Esau's response, וַיֹּאמֶר אֵלָיו הִנֵּנִי (wayyomer 'elav hinneni), "and he said to him, 'Here I am'", employs the term הִנֵּנִי (hinneni), the classic response of readiness and availability. This is the word Abraham spoke when God called him to sacrifice Isaac; this is the word that signifies complete attention and willingness to obey. Esau speaks it to his earthly father, ready to serve Isaac's desires, prepared to hunt the game that will earn him the blessing. The irony is profound: Esau who despised his birthright now eagerly responds to receive the blessing; the man who could not wait for bread will now go hunting to prepare an elaborate meal; the son who traded eternal inheritance for momentary satisfaction will expend great effort to obtain what he has already forfeited.

Isaac's Charge to Esau: The Plan for Blessing
Isaac explains his intention with reference to his own mortality: הִנֵּה־נָא זָקַנְתִּי לֹא יָדַעְתִּי יוֹם מוֹתִי (hinneh-na' zaqanti lo' yada'ti yom moti), "Behold, I am old; I do not know the day of my death." The acknowledgment of approaching death creates urgency; Isaac believes his time is short and wishes to bestow the blessing before he dies. The phrase לֹא יָדַעְתִּי יוֹם מוֹתִי (lo' yada'ti yom moti), "I do not know the day of my death," expresses the universal human ignorance of mortality's timing. Yet Isaac will live many more years, he is present when Jacob returns from Paddan-Aram and will not die until after Jacob's long sojourn with Laban. The patriarch's sense of imminent death, while subjectively genuine, proves objectively mistaken. Perhaps this very urgency, this pressure of perceived mortality, contributes to Isaac's determination to bless Esau quickly, before circumstances can intervene.

The instructions Isaac gives are detailed and specific: וְעַתָּה שָׂא־נָא כֵלֶיךָ תֶּלְיְךָ וְקַשְׁתֶּךָ וְצֵא הַשָּׂדֶה וְצוּדָה לִּי צָיִד (we'attah sa'-na' kheleykha telyekha weqashtekha wetse' hassadeh wetsudah li tsayid), "Now then, take your weapons, your quiver and your bow, and go out to the field and hunt game for me." The כֵּלִים (kelim), "weapons" or "implements," the תֶּלִי (teli), "quiver," and the קֶשֶׁת (qeshet), "bow," are the equipment of the hunter, the tools of Esau's trade. Isaac sends Esau to the שָׂדֶה (sadeh), "the field," that realm outside the domestic encampment where Esau is master, where his skills define him, where he operates as אִישׁ שָׂדֶה ('ish sadeh), "man of the field." The verb צוּד (tsud), "to hunt," from which צַיִד (tsayid), "game," derives, describes Esau's characteristic activity, the pursuit and capture that have defined his identity since youth.

The purpose of the hunt is explicitly culinary and ultimately sacramental: וַעֲשֵׂה־לִי מַטְעַמִּים כַּאֲשֶׁר אָהַבְתִּי וְהָבִיאָה לִּי וְאֹכֵלָה בַּעֲבוּר תְּבָרֶכְךָ נַפְשִׁי בְּטֶרֶם אָמוּת (wa'aseh-li mat'ammim ka'asher 'ahavti wehavi'ah li we'okhelah ba'avur tevarakhekha nafshi beterem 'amut), "and prepare for me delicious food, such as I love, and bring it to me so that I may eat, that my soul may bless you before I die." The noun מַטְעַמִּים (mat'ammim), "delicious food" or "savory dishes," derives from the root טָעַם (ta'am), "to taste, perceive, discern." The term suggests food that pleases the palate, that satisfies the sense of taste, that gratifies appetite. Isaac's blessing is to be preceded by and connected to the satisfaction of his appetite; the spiritual act of patriarchal benediction is intertwined with the physical act of eating savory game.

The phrase כַּאֲשֶׁר אָהַבְתִּי (ka'asher 'ahavti), "such as I love," reinforces the connection between Isaac's preference for Esau and Isaac's preference for game that was established in the previous chapter: "Isaac loved Esau because he had a taste for game" (Genesis 25:28). The father's love for the son is mediated through the son's provision of the food the father loves. This is not purely mercenary, Isaac genuinely favors Esau, but the connection between paternal affection and gustatory satisfaction is repeatedly emphasized in the narrative. Isaac's soul (נַפְשִׁי, nafshi) will bless Esau, but that soul is prepared for blessing by the satisfaction of bodily appetite. The blessing, which should flow from spiritual discernment and prophetic perception of God's purposes, is instead occasioned by the pleasures of the palate.

Rebekah's Intervention: Maternal Conspiracy
The narrative reveals that the conversation between Isaac and Esau was not private: וְרִבְקָה שֹׁמַעַת (weRivqah shoma'at), "and Rebekah was listening." The participle שֹׁמַעַת (shoma'at), "listening" or "hearing," indicates continuous action; Rebekah was in a position to overhear the exchange between father and son, perhaps intentionally stationed to monitor developments in a household she knew was moving toward crisis. The verb שָׁמַע (shama') means not merely to hear acoustically but to pay attention, to understand, to take seriously what is heard. Rebekah hears and understands the significance of what Isaac is planning; she recognizes that the blessing intended for Jacob according to the divine oracle is about to be bestowed upon Esau according to paternal preference.

Rebekah's response is swift and decisive. She summons Jacob and informs him of what she has overheard: הִנֵּה שָׁמַעְתִּי אֶת־אָבִיךָ מְדַבֵּר אֶל־עֵשָׂו אָחִיךָ לֵאמֹר (hinneh shama'ti 'et-'avikha medabber 'el-'Esav 'achikha le'mor), "Behold, I heard your father speaking to Esau your brother, saying." She recounts Isaac's instructions regarding the hunt, the preparation of food, and the intended blessing. The detail of her account indicates careful attention; she has grasped the full scope of Isaac's plan and communicates it precisely to Jacob. The phrase אֶת־אָבִיךָ ('et-'avikha), "your father," and אָחִיךָ ('achikha), "your brother," frame the situation in familial terms while also subtly suggesting distance: this is your father and your brother, but their conspiracy threatens you.

Rebekah then issues her counter-instructions with maternal authority: וְעַתָּה בְנִי שְׁמַע בְּקֹלִי לַאֲשֶׁר אֲנִי מְצַוָּה אֹתָךְ (we'attah veni shema' beqoli la'asher 'ani metsavvah 'otakh), "Now therefore, my son, obey my voice as I command you." The phrase שְׁמַע בְּקֹלִי (shema' beqoli), "listen to my voice" or "obey my voice," uses the same verb that described her listening, now turned into an imperative for Jacob's obedience. The noun קוֹל (qol), "voice," will become thematically significant as the narrative progresses; it will be Jacob's voice that nearly betrays him when he stands before Isaac. Rebekah commands Jacob to heed her voice, her instructions, her plan; she positions herself as the directing authority in this conspiracy, the mastermind who will orchestrate the deception.

The plan she unfolds involves substitution at multiple levels: לֶךְ־נָא אֶל־הַצֹּאן וְקַח־לִי מִשָּׁם שְׁנֵי גְּדָיֵי עִזִּים טֹבִים (lekh-na' 'el-hattso'n weqach-li misham sheney gedayey 'izzim tovim), "Go to the flock and bring me two good young goats." Instead of wild game hunted in the field, domesticated goats from the household flock. Instead of Esau's expertise as hunter, Jacob's availability as obedient son. Instead of the food Isaac requested, food Rebekah will prepare to taste identical. The עִזִּים ('izzim), "goats," are the domesticated animals of the pastoral household, the opposite of the wild צַיִד (tsayid) that Esau has gone to hunt. Rebekah will transform these domestic animals into מַטְעַמִּים (mat'ammim), "delicious food," indistinguishable from the game Isaac loves.

The purpose is stated without equivocation: וְהֵבֵאתָ לְאָבִיךָ וְאָכָל בַּעֲבֻר אֲשֶׁר יְבָרֶכְךָ לִפְנֵי מוֹתוֹ (weheveta le'avikha we'akhal ba'avur 'asher yevarakhekha lifney moto), "and you shall bring it to your father to eat, so that he may bless you before his death." Rebekah explicitly intends for Jacob to receive the blessing that Isaac intends for Esau. She is not merely interfering with Isaac's plan but actively redirecting it, ensuring that the blessing reaches the son to whom, in her understanding, it rightfully belongs. Her knowledge of the prenatal oracle, "the elder shall serve the younger", presumably informs her conviction that she is acting in accordance with divine purpose, even as her method involves systematic deception of her husband.

Jacob's Hesitation: Fear of Detection and Curse
Jacob's response to his mother's plan reveals not moral scruple about the deception itself but practical concern about its viability: וַיֹּאמֶר יַעֲקֹב אֶל־רִבְקָה אִמּוֹ הֵן עֵשָׂו אָחִי אִישׁ שָׂעִר וְאָנֹכִי אִישׁ חָלָק (wayyomer Ya'aqov 'el-Rivqah 'immo hen 'Esav 'achi 'ish sa'ir we'anokhi 'ish chalaq), "And Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, 'Behold, my brother Esau is a hairy man, and I am a smooth man.'" The contrast between שָׂעִר (sa'ir), "hairy," and חָלָק (chalaq), "smooth," recalls the description of Esau at birth, when he emerged כְּאַדֶּרֶת שֵׂעָר (ke'adderet se'ar), "like a hairy garment." The שְׂעִירוּת (se'irut), "hairiness," that characterized Esau from birth remains his distinguishing physical feature, and Jacob recognizes this as the primary obstacle to successful impersonation. Isaac may be blind, but he can touch; and touch will reveal the smooth skin of Jacob rather than the hairy pelt of Esau.

Jacob's concern extends to the consequences of detection: אוּלַי יְמֻשֵּׁנִי אָבִי וְהָיִיתִי בְעֵינָיו כִּמְתַעְתֵּעַ וְהֵבֵאתִי עָלַי קְלָלָה וְלֹא בְרָכָה ('ulay yemusheni 'avi wehayiti ve'eynav kimta'tea' weheveti 'alay qelalah welo' verakhah), "Perhaps my father will feel me, and I shall seem to him as a deceiver, and I shall bring upon myself a curse and not a blessing." The verb מוּשׁ (mush) or יָמֵשׁ (yamesh), "to feel, touch, handle," identifies the sensory modality that Isaac retains and that poses the greatest danger to the deception. Jacob fears that he will be discovered to be a מְתַעְתֵּעַ (meta'tea'), "mocker, deceiver, one who deals falsely." This term, from the root תָּעַע (ta'a'), carries strong connotations of mockery and contempt; to be revealed as such would be shameful and would transform the intended blessing into a curse.

The opposition between קְלָלָה (qelalah), "curse," and בְרָכָה (verakhah), "blessing," frames Jacob's dilemma in its starkest terms. He seeks blessing but fears curse; he desires the paternal benediction but dreads the paternal imprecation. The stakes could not be higher: patriarchal blessing and curse were understood to carry real power, to set in motion forces that would shape the recipient's future. A curse from Isaac, pronounced upon discovering Jacob's deception, could undo everything the blessing was meant to accomplish. Jacob's hesitation is not ethical sensitivity but risk assessment; he is calculating whether the potential gain is worth the potential loss.

Rebekah's response sweeps away Jacob's objections with maternal authority and self-implication: עָלַי קִלְלָתְךָ בְּנִי אַךְ שְׁמַע בְּקֹלִי ('alay qillatekha beni 'akh shema' beqoli), "Upon me be your curse, my son; only obey my voice." The phrase עָלַי קִלְלָתְךָ ('alay qillatekha), "upon me your curse," is a remarkable assumption of liability. Rebekah takes upon herself any curse that might result from the deception; she interposes herself between Jacob and the consequences of discovery. The אַךְ ('akh), "only" or "surely," emphasizes the singular imperative that follows: שְׁמַע בְּקֹלִי (shema' beqoli), "obey my voice." Whatever risks may exist, whatever curses may result, Rebekah will bear them; Jacob's sole responsibility is obedience to his mother's direction.

This assumption of the curse by the mother on behalf of the son carries typological weight that will be explored below. Rebekah places herself in the position of curse-bearer, taking upon herself the liability that rightly belongs to the one who performs the deception. She does not diminish the seriousness of potential curse; she acknowledges it and accepts it, freeing Jacob to act by absorbing the consequences onto herself. Whether Rebekah fully understood the theological significance of her words or simply spoke from maternal determination, the pattern she establishes, one person bearing the curse that another deserves, resonates throughout Scripture until its ultimate fulfillment in Christ who became a curse for us.

The Preparation: Goats, Garments, and Skins
Jacob obeys his mother's command, and the preparations for deception proceed: וַיֵּלֶךְ וַיִּקַּח וַיָּבֵא לְאִמּוֹ וַתַּעַשׂ אִמּוֹ מַטְעַמִּים כַּאֲשֶׁר אָהֵב אָבִיו (wayyelekh wayyiqqach wayyave' le'immo watta'as 'immo mat'ammim ka'asher 'ahev 'aviv), "So he went and took and brought them to his mother, and his mother prepared delicious food, such as his father loved." The rapid sequence of verbs, וַיֵּלֶךְ... וַיִּקַּח... וַיָּבֵא (wayyelekh... wayyiqqach... wayyave'), "he went... he took... he brought", conveys the swift execution of Rebekah's instructions. Jacob acts without further hesitation; having received his mother's assurance regarding the curse, he becomes an efficient instrument of her plan.

Rebekah's culinary skill is emphasized: she prepares מַטְעַמִּים כַּאֲשֶׁר אָהֵב אָבִיו (mat'ammim ka'asher 'ahev 'aviv), "delicious food such as his father loved." The domesticated goat meat is transformed into a dish indistinguishable from the wild game Isaac craves. This is no mean feat; wild game and domestic goat have different flavors and textures, and a man with sophisticated culinary preferences, as Isaac's love for savory game suggests, might detect the difference. But Rebekah, who has shared Isaac's table for decades, knows exactly how to prepare food that will satisfy his palate. The deception of taste succeeds because Rebekah understands her husband's appetites and knows how to gratify them.

The disguise extends beyond food to clothing: וַתִּקַּח רִבְקָה אֶת־בִּגְדֵי עֵשָׂו בְּנָהּ הַגָּדֹל הַחֲמֻדֹת אֲשֶׁר אִתָּהּ בַּבָּיִת וַתַּלְבֵּשׁ אֶת־יַעֲקֹב בְּנָהּ הַקָּטָן (wattiqqach Rivqah 'et-bigdey 'Esav benah haggadol hachamudot 'asher 'ittah babbayit wattalbesh 'et-Ya'aqov benah haqqatan), "And Rebekah took the best garments of Esau her elder son, which were with her in the house, and put them on Jacob her younger son." The בִּגְדֵי... הַחֲמֻדֹת (bigdey... hachamudot), "the desirable garments" or "the best garments," were apparently kept in Rebekah's custody rather than in Esau's own quarters. The adjective חָמוּד (chamud), from the root חָמַד (chamad), "to desire, covet, delight in," indicates garments of particular value or significance, perhaps ceremonial clothing worn on special occasions, garments associated with the firstborn's dignity.

The contrast between הַגָּדֹל (haggadol), "the elder," and הַקָּטָן (haqqatan), "the younger," emphasizes the reversal being enacted: the younger son is being dressed in the elder son's garments, assuming his identity, taking his place. The clothing that belongs to Esau now adorns Jacob; the external markers of the firstborn are transferred to the second-born. Clothing in the ancient world carried tremendous significance, communicating status, identity, and role. By dressing Jacob in Esau's best garments, Rebekah effects a symbolic transformation: Jacob becomes, externally at least, what Esau is supposed to be.

The most remarkable element of the disguise addresses Jacob's earlier concern about his smooth skin: וְאֵת עֹרֹת גְּדָיֵי הָעִזִּים הִלְבִּישָׁה עַל־יָדָיו וְעַל חֶלְקַת צַוָּארָיו (we'et 'orot gedayey ha'izzim hilbishah 'al-yadav we'al chelqat tsavva'rav), "And the skins of the young goats she put on his hands and on the smooth part of his neck." The עֹרֹת ('orot), "skins," of the slaughtered goats now serve a second purpose: having provided the meat for the savory dish, they now provide the covering for Jacob's smooth skin. The יָדַיִם (yadayim), "hands," and the צַוָּאר (tsavva'r), "neck," are the areas most likely to be touched by the blind Isaac; these are covered with goat skin to simulate Esau's hairy texture. The term חֶלְקַת (chelqat), "smooth part," explicitly recalls Jacob's earlier self-description as אִישׁ חָלָק ('ish chalaq), "a smooth man"; the smoothness that threatened to betray him is now concealed beneath animal hide.

The image is striking and somewhat grotesque: a man wearing the flayed skins of goats on his hands and neck, impersonating his brother by simulating hairiness with animal pelts. The deception operates at the most physical level, manipulating the sense of touch to create a false impression. Yet there is also something deeply symbolic in Jacob wearing animal skins. Adam and Eve, after their sin, were clothed by God with animal skins; now Jacob, in pursuit of blessing through deception, covers himself with skins to accomplish his purpose. The covering of skin conceals his true identity, allowing him to present himself as other than he is.

The Approach: Jacob Before Isaac
The preparations complete, Rebekah sends Jacob to his father with the food and bread: וַתִּתֵּן אֶת־הַמַּטְעַמִּים וְאֶת־הַלֶּחֶם אֲשֶׁר עָשָׂתָה בְּיַד יַעֲקֹב בְּנָהּ (wattitten 'et-hammat'ammim we'et-hallechem 'asher 'asatah beyad Ya'aqov benah), "And she put the delicious food and the bread that she had prepared into the hand of Jacob her son." The combination of מַטְעַמִּים (mat'ammim), "delicious food," and לֶחֶם (lechem), "bread," constitutes a complete meal. Armed with this meal and disguised in his brother's garments and goat skins, Jacob enters his father's presence.

The encounter begins with Jacob's announcement: וַיָּבֹא אֶל־אָבִיו וַיֹּאמֶר אָבִי (wayyavo' 'el-'aviv wayyomer 'avi), "And he went in to his father and said, 'My father. '" The simple address אָבִי ('avi), "my father," begins the verbal exchange that will test the deception's viability. Isaac responds with acknowledgment and inquiry: וַיֹּאמֶר הִנֶּנִּי מִי אַתָּה בְּנִי (wayyomer hinneni mi 'attah beni), "And he said, 'Here I am. Who are you, my son?'" The question מִי אַתָּה (mi 'attah), "who are you," immediately exposes the vulnerability of Isaac's condition; he cannot identify by sight the person standing before him. The blind patriarch must rely on other senses and on the truthfulness of the responses he receives.

Jacob's answer is the central lie of the narrative: וַיֹּאמֶר יַעֲקֹב אֶל־אָבִיו אָנֹכִי עֵשָׂו בְּכֹרֶךָ (wayyomer Ya'aqov 'el-'aviv 'anokhi 'Esav bekhorekha), "And Jacob said to his father, 'I am Esau your firstborn. '" The statement אָנֹכִי עֵשָׂו ('anokhi 'Esav), "I am Esau," is a direct falsehood, a claim to an identity that is not his own. The addition of בְּכֹרֶךָ (bekhorekha), "your firstborn," compounds the lie by claiming not merely Esau's name but Esau's status, the status that Esau had sold to Jacob for lentil stew. In a strange sense, Jacob is both lying and telling a distorted truth: he is not Esau, but he does possess the birthright that makes someone the בְּכֹר (bekhor). The firstborn status that Isaac assumes belongs to Esau has in fact been legally transferred to Jacob. Yet the manner of Jacob's claim is unmistakably deceptive; he presents himself as Esau, not as the one who purchased Esau's birthright.

Jacob continues with an explanation of his quick return: עָשִׂיתִי כַּאֲשֶׁר דִּבַּרְתָּ אֵלָי קוּם־נָא שְׁבָה וְאָכְלָה מִצֵּידִי בַּעֲבוּר תְּבָרְכַנִּי נַפְשֶׁךָ ('asiti ka'asher dibbarta 'elay qum-na' shevah we'okhlah mitseydi ba'avur tevarakhanni nafshekha), "I have done as you told me; now sit up and eat of my game, that your soul may bless me." Jacob claims to have fulfilled Isaac's instructions, to have hunted and prepared the game as commanded. The term מִצֵּידִי (mitseydi), "of my game" or "from my hunting," is false, the food is goat meat, not hunted game, but it maintains the fiction that Esau has returned from a successful hunt. The invitation to eat and bless follows the pattern Isaac established in his original instructions to Esau.

Isaac's Suspicion: The Probing Questions
Isaac's first response reveals the suspicion that the speed of return has aroused: וַיֹּאמֶר יִצְחָק אֶל־בְּנוֹ מַה־זֶּה מִהַרְתָּ לִמְצֹא בְּנִי (wayyomer Yitschaq 'el-beno mah-zeh miharta limtso' beni), "And Isaac said to his son, 'How is it that you have found it so quickly, my son?'" The verb מִהַר (mihar), "to hasten, be quick," highlights the problem: hunting wild game, tracking it, killing it, and preparing it into savory food is time-consuming work. Esau has been gone only a short while, yet here is the food ready to eat. Isaac's blind eyes cannot see the deception, but his mind can note the improbability of such rapid success.

Jacob's response invokes divine assistance: וַיֹּאמֶר כִּי הִקְרָה יְהוָה אֱלֹהֶיךָ לְפָנָי (wayyomer ki hiqrah YHWH 'Eloheykha lefanay), "And he said, 'Because the LORD your God granted me success. '" The verb הִקְרָה (hiqrah), from קָרָה (qarah), "to encounter, meet, happen upon," with the Hiphil indicating causation, suggests that God caused game to come into Jacob's path, making the hunt swift and successful. This is a theologically audacious lie: Jacob claims divine assistance for a deception, attributes to Yahweh the success of a fraud, invokes the covenant God as patron of his impersonation. The phrase יְהוָה אֱלֹהֶיךָ (YHWH 'Eloheykha), "the LORD your God," may itself be a subtle slip; Esau would more likely say "the LORD my God" or simply "the LORD," while Jacob's distancing formulation, "your God", perhaps betrays his awareness that he is engaged in an act that puts him outside the sphere of divine favor.

Isaac remains uncertain, and his suspicion finds expression in a request for closer examination: וַיֹּאמֶר יִצְחָק אֶל־יַעֲקֹב גְּשָׁה־נָּא וַאֲמֻשְׁךָ בְּנִי הַאַתָּה זֶה בְּנִי עֵשָׂו אִם־לֹא (wayyomer Yitschaq 'el-Ya'aqov geshah-na' wa'amushkha beni ha'attah zeh beni 'Esav 'im-lo'), "And Isaac said to Jacob, 'Come near, that I may feel you, my son, to know whether you are really my son Esau or not.'" The verb מוּשׁ (mush), "to feel, touch," is precisely what Jacob had feared. Isaac, unable to trust sight, will employ touch to verify identity. The question הַאַתָּה זֶה בְּנִי עֵשָׂו אִם־לֹא (ha'attah zeh beni 'Esav 'im-lo'), "are you really my son Esau or not," expresses genuine doubt; something does not seem right, and Isaac seeks tactile confirmation.

Jacob submits to the examination: וַיִּגַּשׁ יַעֲקֹב אֶל־יִצְחָק אָבִיו וַיְמֻשֵּׁהוּ (wayyiggash Ya'aqov 'el-Yitschaq 'aviv wayemushhehu), "So Jacob went near to Isaac his father, and he felt him." The goat skins are now put to the test. Isaac's hands move over Jacob's hands and neck, feeling for the telltale hairiness that would identify Esau. The moment is tense: will the animal skins succeed in deceiving the patriarch's touch? Will the covering hold, or will some portion of smooth skin betray the fraud?

Isaac's response reveals the paradox that will define this scene: וַיֹּאמֶר הַקֹּל קוֹל יַעֲקֹב וְהַיָּדַיִם יְדֵי עֵשָׂו (wayyomer haqqol qol Ya'aqov wehayadayim yedey 'Esav), "And he said, 'The voice is Jacob's voice, but the hands are the hands of Esau.'" The קוֹל (qol), "voice," betrays Jacob; even attempting to speak as Esau would speak, something in the timbre, the cadence, the characteristic patterns of speech identifies the voice as Jacob's. But the יָדַיִם (yadayim), "hands," covered with goat skin, feel like Esau's hands. Isaac is confronted with contradictory sensory evidence: ears say Jacob, hands say Esau. The blind patriarch cannot reconcile what he hears with what he feels.

The narrative explains the reason for Isaac's eventual acceptance: וְלֹא הִכִּירוֹ כִּי־הָיוּ יָדָיו כִּידֵי עֵשָׂו אָחִיו שְׂעִרֹת (welo' hikkiro ki-hayu yadav kidey 'Esav 'achiv se'irot), "He did not recognize him, because his hands were hairy like his brother Esau's hands." The verb הִכִּיר (hikkir), "to recognize, acknowledge, discern," indicates that Isaac failed to identify Jacob as Jacob; the disguise held sufficiently to prevent recognition. The hairiness of the hands, שְׂעִרֹת (se'irot), "hairy," echoing Esau's characteristic שֵׂעָר (se'ar), proved more persuasive than the voice's true quality. Touch trumped hearing; the goat skins overrode the vocal identification. Isaac's blindness, which forced reliance on non-visual senses, ultimately led him to trust the wrong sense and dismiss the one that was giving him accurate information.

The Blessing Pronounced: Isaac's Benediction
Before pronouncing the formal blessing, Isaac asks once more for confirmation: וַיֹּאמֶר אַתָּה זֶה בְּנִי עֵשָׂו (wayyomer 'attah zeh beni 'Esav), "And he said, 'Are you really my son Esau? '" The repetition of the question indicates lingering doubt, a reluctance to proceed without final assurance. Jacob's response is terse and direct: וַיֹּאמֶר אָנִי (wayyomer 'ani), "And he said, 'I am. '" The single word אָנִי ('ani), "I," is an affirmation of identity, though deliberately ambiguous. Jacob says "I am" without explicitly repeating "I am Esau"; yet in context, the response can only be understood as confirmation of the Esau identity. The deception is complete; Isaac's final doubt is resolved, wrongly, in favor of proceeding with the blessing.

Isaac requests the food: וַיֹּאמֶר הַגִּשָׁה לִּי וְאֹכְלָה מִצֵּיד בְּנִי לְמַעַן תְּבָרֶכְךָ נַפְשִׁי (wayyomer haggisah li we'okhlah mitseyd beni lema'an tevarakhekha nafshi), "And he said, 'Bring it near to me, that I may eat of my son's game and then bless you.'" The sequence is maintained: eating precedes blessing, the satisfaction of appetite prepares the soul for benediction. Jacob serves the meal: וַיַּגֶּשׁ־לוֹ וַיֹּאכַל וַיָּבֵא לוֹ יַיִן וַיֵּשְׁתְּ (wayyaggesh-lo wayyokhal wayyave' lo yayin wayyesht), "And he brought it near to him, and he ate; and he brought him wine, and he drank." The addition of יַיִן (yayin), "wine," enhances the meal's festive character; this is not merely nourishment but celebration, the kind of meal appropriate to a blessing ceremony. Isaac eats and drinks, his appetite satisfied, his senses pleased, his suspicions quieted by the gratification of the flesh.

One final test remains. Isaac requests physical proximity: וַיֹּאמֶר אֵלָיו יִצְחָק אָבִיו גְּשָׁה־נָּא וּשְׁקָה־לִּי בְּנִי (wayyomer 'elav Yitschaq 'aviv geshah-na' ushqah-li beni), "Then his father Isaac said to him, 'Come near and kiss me, my son. '" The kiss of blessing, the embrace of father and son preceding the formal benediction, this brings Jacob into closest physical contact with his father since the initial touching of hands. Jacob obeys: וַיִּגַּשׁ וַיִּשַּׁק־לוֹ (wayyiggash wayyishaq-lo), "And he came near and kissed him."

In this intimate moment, Isaac employs another sense: וַיָּרַח אֶת־רֵיחַ בְּגָדָיו (wayyarach 'et-reyach begadav), "and he smelled the smell of his garments." The verb רוּחַ (ruach) in the Hiphil, "to smell," introduces the olfactory sense. Isaac inhales the scent of the clothing Jacob wears, Esau's garments, carrying the distinctive odor of the hunter, the smell of the field, the aroma that Isaac associates with his favored son. This smell provides the final confirmation: וַיְבָרְכֵהוּ (wayevarakhehu), "and he blessed him." The blessing proceeds, authorized by the smell of garments that belong to Esau even though worn by Jacob.

The blessing itself is poetic, powerful, and comprehensive:

רְאֵה רֵיחַ בְּנִי כְּרֵיחַ שָׂדֶה אֲשֶׁר בֵּרְכוֹ יְהוָה
(re'eh reyach beni kereyach sadeh 'asher berako YHWH)
"See, the smell of my son is as the smell of a field that the LORD has blessed!"

The blessing begins with the very scent that has just satisfied Isaac's doubt. The son smells like a blessed field, like the productive earth that yields its abundance under divine favor. The שָׂדֶה (sadeh), "field," that is Esau's characteristic realm is here invoked as the realm of divine blessing.

וְיִתֶּן־לְךָ הָאֱלֹהִים מִטַּל הַשָּׁמַיִם וּמִשְׁמַנֵּי הָאָרֶץ וְרֹב דָּגָן וְתִירֹשׁ
(weyitten-lekha ha'Elohim mittal hashamayim umishmanney ha'arets werov dagan wetirosh)
"May God give you of the dew of heaven and of the fatness of the earth and plenty of grain and wine."

The blessing invokes divine provision: טַל הַשָּׁמַיִם (tal hashamayim), "dew of heaven," the moisture that descends from above to water the earth; שְׁמַנֵּי הָאָרֶץ (shmanney ha'arets), "fatness of the earth," the rich fertility that produces abundance; רֹב דָּגָן וְתִירֹשׁ (rov dagan wetirosh), "plenty of grain and wine," the staples of agricultural prosperity. This is blessing in its material dimension, fertility, abundance, prosperity flowing from divine generosity.

יַעַבְדוּךָ עַמִּים וְיִשְׁתַּחֲווּ לְךָ לְאֻמִּים
(ya'avdukha 'ammim weyishtachavu lekha le'ummim)
"Let peoples serve you, and nations bow down to you."

The blessing expands to political dominion: עַמִּים ('ammim), "peoples," shall serve the blessed one; לְאֻמִּים (le'ummim), "nations," shall prostrate themselves before him. The language echoes the prenatal oracle, where two גוֹיִם (goyim), "nations," and two לְאֻמִּים (le'ummim), "peoples," were in Rebekah's womb. The blessing that Isaac intends for Esau is precisely the blessing that the oracle assigned to Jacob: dominion over nations, the service of peoples.

הֱוֵה גְבִיר לְאַחֶיךָ וְיִשְׁתַּחֲווּ לְךָ בְּנֵי אִמֶּךָ
(heveh gevir le'acheykha weyishtachavu lekha beney 'immekha)
"Be lord over your brothers, and may your mother's sons bow down to you."

The blessing specifies family dominion: the blessed one shall be גְּבִיר (gevir), "lord" or "master," over his brothers; the sons of his mother shall bow before him. Isaac intends this as Esau's lordship over Jacob; ironically, it becomes Jacob's lordship over Esau, exactly as the oracle declared. The phrase בְּנֵי אִמֶּךָ (beney 'immekha), "sons of your mother," rather than "sons of your father," may reflect the particular configuration of Isaac's family where one mother bore two sons, or may be a standard idiom for full brothers as opposed to half-brothers.

אֹרְרֶיךָ אָרוּר וּמְבָרְכֶיךָ בָּרוּךְ
('orerekha 'arur umvarakhekha barukh)
"Cursed be everyone who curses you, and blessed be everyone who blesses you."

The final element of the blessing establishes the blessed one as a nexus of blessing and curse for others. Those who curse him will themselves be cursed; those who bless him will themselves be blessed. This is the Abrahamic blessing in its characteristic form: "I will bless those who bless you, and him who dishonors you I will curse" (Genesis 12:3). Whether Isaac consciously echoes the Abrahamic formula or whether the tradition of patriarchal blessing simply runs in these channels, the effect is to transfer to the recipient the same protective and distributive blessing that characterized Abraham himself.

Esau's Return: Discovery and Anguish
The deception accomplished, Jacob departs: וַיְהִי כַּאֲשֶׁר כִּלָּה יִצְחָק לְבָרֵךְ אֶת־יַעֲקֹב וַיְהִי אַךְ יָצֹא יָצָא יַעֲקֹב מֵאֵת פְּנֵי יִצְחָק אָבִיו וְעֵשָׂו אָחִיו בָּא מִצֵּידוֹ (wayehi ka'asher killah Yitschaq levarekh 'et-Ya'aqov wayehi 'akh yatso' yatsa' Ya'aqov me'et peney Yitschaq 'aviv we'Esav 'achiv ba' mitseydo), "As soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, and Jacob had scarcely gone out from the presence of Isaac his father, Esau his brother came in from his hunting." The timing is dramatically precise: אַךְ יָצֹא יָצָא ('akh yatso' yatsa'), "he had just, just gone out", the doubled infinitive absolute emphasizes how narrow the margin was. Jacob leaves; Esau arrives. Had Esau returned minutes earlier, he would have encountered Jacob in Isaac's tent; the deception would have been exposed in the act. Providence or luck, depending on one's theological reading, allowed Jacob to escape just before Esau's return.

Esau performs exactly the actions Isaac had commanded: וַיַּעַשׂ גַּם־הוּא מַטְעַמִּים וַיָּבֵא לְאָבִיו (wayya'as gam-hu' mat'ammim wayyave' le'aviv), "He also prepared delicious food and brought it to his father." The גַּם־הוּא (gam-hu'), "he also," creates the parallel that exposes the substitution. Esau has done what Jacob claimed to have done; he has hunted, prepared, and brought savory food. His approach to Isaac mirrors Jacob's: וַיֹּאמֶר לְאָבִיו יָקֻם אָבִי וְיֹאכַל מִצֵּיד בְּנוֹ בַּעֲבוּר תְּבָרְכַנִּי נַפְשֶׁךָ (wayyomer le'aviv yaqum 'avi weyokhal mitseyd beno ba'avur tevarakhanni nafshekha), "And he said to his father, 'Let my father arise and eat of his son's game, that your soul may bless me. '" The language is nearly identical to Jacob's; the expectation is the same.

Isaac's response reveals dawning horror: וַיֹּאמֶר לוֹ יִצְחָק אָבִיו מִי־אָתָּה (wayyomer lo Yitschaq 'aviv mi-'attah), "And Isaac his father said to him, 'Who are you?'" The question that began the encounter with Jacob, מִי אַתָּה (mi 'attah), "who are you", is now repeated to Esau, but with entirely different import. Before, it was the question of a blind man seeking identification; now, it is the question of a horrified man realizing that something has gone terribly wrong. If this person before him is claiming to be Esau, then who was the person he just blessed?

Esau answers with the identity that should have been obvious: וַיֹּאמֶר אֲנִי בִּנְךָ בְכֹרְךָ עֵשָׂו (wayyomer 'ani binkha bekhorekha 'Esav), "And he said, 'I am your son, your firstborn, Esau.'" The threefold identification, בִּנְךָ (binkha), "your son," בְכֹרְךָ (bekhorekha), "your firstborn," עֵשָׂו ('Esav), "Esau", emphasizes the identity that has been usurped. Esau is indeed Isaac's son, is indeed the biological firstborn, is indeed Esau. But the blessing intended for this son, this firstborn, this Esau, has already been given to another.

Isaac's reaction is described with physical intensity: וַיֶּחֱרַד יִצְחָק חֲרָדָה גְּדֹלָה עַד־מְאֹד (wayyecherad Yitschaq charadah gedolah 'ad-me'od), "And Isaac trembled very violently." The verb חָרַד (charad), "to tremble, be terrified," intensified by the cognate accusative חֲרָדָה גְּדֹלָה (charadah gedolah), "a great trembling," and further intensified by עַד־מְאֹד ('ad-me'od), "exceedingly," conveys extreme physical and emotional distress. Isaac shakes with the realization of what has occurred, he has blessed the wrong son, has been deceived in his own tent, has pronounced irrevocable blessing upon one who obtained it through fraud.

Yet Isaac's next words reveal something beyond horror: a recognition that what has happened, however it happened, is now fixed and final: וַיֹּאמֶר מִי־אֵפוֹא הוּא הַצָּד־צַיִד וַיָּבֵא לִי וָאֹכַל מִכֹּל בְּטֶרֶם תָּבוֹא וָאֲבָרְכֵהוּ גַּם־בָּרוּךְ יִהְיֶה (wayyomer mi-'efo' hu' hatststad-tsayid wayyave' li va'okhal mikkol beterem tavo' va'avarakehu gam-barukh yihyeh), "And he said, 'Who then is the one who hunted game and brought it to me, and I ate it all before you came, and I blessed him? Yes, and he shall be blessed. '" The final phrase, גַּם־בָּרוּךְ יִהְיֶה (gam-barukh yihyeh), "yes, he shall be blessed" or "indeed, blessed he shall be", is the crucial theological statement. Isaac does not say, "I will revoke the blessing"; he does not say, "the blessing was obtained by fraud and is therefore void." He says, with trembling but with finality, that the blessing stands. The one who received it, however he received it, shall be blessed.

This recognition that the blessing cannot be revoked reflects the ancient understanding of the power of spoken words, especially blessings and curses pronounced by patriarchs and authorized speakers. Once the words were spoken, they took on independent existence; they could not be unsaid or recalled. The blessing had gone forth from Isaac's mouth, had attached itself to the recipient, had begun its work in the spiritual realm. No subsequent discovery of fraud could undo what had been done. Isaac trembles because he recognizes that he has been the instrument of something he did not intend, that his blessing has accomplished what the divine oracle declared, that his attempt to bless Esau has resulted in the blessing of Jacob. Whether he understands this as divine overruling of his intentions or simply as the irreversibility of patriarchal blessing, the effect is the same: Jacob is blessed, and blessed he shall remain.

Esau's Bitter Cry: The Loss of Blessing
Esau's response to his father's words is one of the most emotionally intense moments in Genesis: כִּשְׁמֹעַ עֵשָׂו אֶת־דִּבְרֵי אָבִיו וַיִּצְעַק צְעָקָה גְּדֹלָה וּמָרָה עַד־מְאֹד (kishmo'a 'Esav 'et-divrey 'aviv wayyits'aq tse'aqah gedolah umarah 'ad-me'od), "When Esau heard the words of his father, he cried out with an exceedingly great and bitter cry." The noun צְעָקָה (tse'aqah), "cry" or "outcry," denotes a loud, anguished vocalization, the kind of scream that erupts from deep grief or pain. The modifiers pile up: גְּדֹלָה (gedolah), "great"; וּמָרָה (umarah), "and bitter"; עַד־מְאֹד ('ad-me'od), "exceedingly." This is not weeping but wailing, not sorrow but anguish, the primal scream of one who has lost everything.

Esau's plea to his father is desperate: וַיֹּאמֶר לְאָבִיו בָּרְכֵנִי גַם־אָנִי אָבִי (wayyomer le'aviv barakheni gam-'ani 'avi), "And he said to his father, 'Bless me, even me also, O my father! '" The repeated emphasis, גַם־אָנִי (gam-'ani), "me also," "even me", expresses Esau's desperate desire for some portion of paternal blessing. The address אָבִי ('avi), "my father," carries pathos; Esau appeals to the paternal bond, to the relationship that should guarantee blessing for a son.

Isaac's explanation names the cause: וַיֹּאמֶר בָּא אָחִיךָ בְּמִרְמָה וַיִּקַּח בִּרְכָתֶךָ (wayyomer ba' 'achikha bemirmah wayyiqqach birkhatekha), "And he said, 'Your brother came deceitfully, and he has taken your blessing. '" The term בְּמִרְמָה (bemirmah), "with deceit" or "deceitfully," from the root רָמָה (ramah), "to deceive, beguile," plainly names what Jacob did. The verb לָקַח (laqach), "to take," might seem milder than גָּזַל (gazal), "to steal, rob," but in context it means the same thing: Jacob has taken what Isaac intended for Esau. The blessing that was בִּרְכָתֶךָ (birkhatekha), "your blessing", belonging to Esau by Isaac's intention, now belongs to another.

Esau's response connects this moment to the earlier birthright transaction: וַיֹּאמֶר הֲכִי קָרָא שְׁמוֹ יַעֲקֹב וַיַּעְקְבֵנִי זֶה פַעֲמַיִם אֶת־בְּכֹרָתִי לָקָח וְהִנֵּה עַתָּה לָקַח בִּרְכָתִי (wayyomer hakhi qara' shemo Ya'aqov wayya'qeveni zeh fa'amayim 'et-bekhorati laqach wehinneh 'attah laqach birkhati), "And he said, 'Is he not rightly named Jacob? For he has cheated me these two times. He took away my birthright, and behold, now he has taken away my blessing. '" Esau interprets Jacob's name as derived from עָקַב ('aqav), "to supplant, cheat, take by the heel," and sees in the name a prediction of Jacob's character. The phrase וַיַּעְקְבֵנִי (wayya'qeveni), "he has cheated me" or "he has supplanted me," puns on the name יַעֲקֹב (Ya'aqov).

The accusation זֶה פַעֲמַיִם (zeh fa'amayim), "these two times," equates the birthright transaction with the blessing theft. Yet the comparison obscures an important difference: Esau sold the birthright voluntarily, however imprudently; Jacob took the blessing through deception. The first transaction, morally complex as it was, involved Esau's consent; the second involved Esau's victimization. But Esau lumps them together as instances of Jacob's supplanting character, refusing to acknowledge his own culpability in despising the birthright.

Esau's final plea is for any remaining blessing: וַיֹּאמֶר הֲלֹא־אָצַלְתָּ לִּי בְּרָכָה (wayyomer halo'-'atsalta li berakhah), "And he said, 'Have you not reserved a blessing for me? '" The verb אָצַל ('atsal), "to reserve, set aside, lay aside," asks whether Isaac has kept anything back, has any blessing remaining that Esau might receive. The desperation of the question is palpable: surely there is something, surely the patriarchal storehouse of blessing is not entirely depleted, surely a father can find some word of benediction for his firstborn son.

Isaac's Response: The Limits of Blessing
Isaac's answer is devastating in its finality: וַיַּעַן יִצְחָק וַיֹּאמֶר לְעֵשָׂו הֵן גְּבִיר שַׂמְתִּיו לָךְ וְאֶת־כָּל־אֶחָיו נָתַתִּי לוֹ לַעֲבָדִים וְדָגָן וְתִירֹשׁ סְמַכְתִּיו וּלְכָה אֵפוֹא מָה אֶעֱשֶׂה בְּנִי (wayya'an Yitschaq wayyomer le'Esav hen gevir samtiv lakh we'et-kol-'echav natatti lo la'avadim wedagan wetirosh semakhtiv ulekha 'efo' mah 'e'eseh beni), "And Isaac answered and said to Esau, 'Behold, I have made him lord over you, and all his brothers I have given to him for servants, and with grain and wine I have sustained him. What then can I do for you, my son?'"

The blessing given to Jacob was comprehensive: lordship (גְּבִיר, gevir), servitude of brothers, provision of grain and wine. These constitute the patriarchal inheritance in its fullness. Isaac's question, מָה אֶעֱשֶׂה (mah 'e'eseh), "what can I do", is not rhetorical evasion but genuine perplexity. The blessing was singular; it has been given; what remains to give? The ancient understanding of blessing assumed a finite quantity of blessing available to bestow; the comprehensive blessing given to Jacob has, in Isaac's understanding, exhausted the supply.

Esau persists with his plea, now with explicit weeping: וַיֹּאמֶר עֵשָׂו אֶל־אָבִיו הַבְרָכָה אַחַת הִוא־לְךָ אָבִי בָּרְכֵנִי גַם־אָנִי אָבִי וַיִּשָּׂא עֵשָׂו קֹלוֹ וַיֵּבְךְּ (wayyomer 'Esav 'el-'aviv haverakhah 'achat hi'-lekha 'avi barakheni gam-'ani 'avi wayyissa' 'Esav qolo wayyevk), "And Esau said to his father, 'Have you but one blessing, my father? Bless me, even me also, O my father.' And Esau lifted up his voice and wept." The question הַבְרָכָה אַחַת הִוא־לְךָ (haverakhah 'achat hi'-lekha), "is there but one blessing for you," challenges the assumption of blessing's finitude. Surely a father as blessed as Isaac, heir of Abraham's abundant blessing, has more than one blessing to bestow? The repetition of בָּרְכֵנִי גַם־אָנִי אָבִי (barakheni gam-'ani 'avi), "bless me, even me also, my father," now accompanied by weeping (וַיֵּבְךְּ, wayyevk), is heart-rending. Esau, the rough hunter, the man of the field, is reduced to tears before his father, begging for blessing.

Isaac finally provides something, not the primary blessing, which cannot be recalled, but a secondary pronouncement that reads more like a destiny than a benediction:

הִנֵּה מִשְׁמַנֵּי הָאָרֶץ יִהְיֶה מוֹשָׁבֶךָ וּמִטַּל הַשָּׁמַיִם מֵעָל
(hinneh mishmanney ha'arets yihyeh moshavekha umittal hashamayim me'al)
"Behold, away from the fatness of the earth shall your dwelling be, and away from the dew of heaven on high."

The preposition מִן (min), "from," is ambiguous: it can mean "of" (partitive) or "away from" (separative). The blessing to Jacob used מִן in the partitive sense, "of the dew of heaven," "of the fatness of the earth," meaning participation in these goods. Many interpreters understand Isaac's words to Esau as using מִן in the separative sense, "away from the fatness," "away from the dew", meaning exclusion from these goods. Esau's dwelling will be in regions lacking the agricultural abundance promised to Jacob. The land of Edom, rocky and a
